review_title: Avoid coming unless you have family in area or are hired in Engineering or Business Depts.
pros: Students are very sincere and respectful; great colleagues; small-town living (if that's your thing); everybody knows everybody (if you like that); mild winters (one to two ice days per annum)
cons: No raises or cost of living adjustments since 2008; cost of living is high (don't listen to what administrators tell you); can't survive on one salary except perhaps if you're alone and don't have to travel (ever) or if you're a coach or Engineering prof; expect to send kids to private schools and pay dearly; no proper daycare facilities for the very young - have to pay for in-home sitter if you don't have relatives available; significantly lower expectations of student capability (despite what they tell you); too many overpaid administrators; promises (even those in writing) are forgotten; easy to get stuck here (who's going to hire you in future, especially if you have tenure?); hot, humid summers that last from May till almost November; no major shops - no mall - in town except for Wal-Mart (and with our workload you can't just drive to closest 'major' cities on the weekend to shop

review_title: Great people, but the State is leading the charge to the bottom in continual slashing of budgets.
pros: Most folk are here because they feel called to teach.
cons: Admins mouth "we are family" while finding ways to cut people without technically firing them (so they can say they didn't fire people). Budgets are murder - we rank at the bottom in the nation for pay, and not only is pay very low with no raises for 6 years, but operating budgets are cut so that we have to buy supplies from our own pockets. One colleague is thinking of applying for food stamps. Most of us have cut back on phone, cable, whatever we can. And still no raises. Work loads increase; more students per class, more paperwork (as administrative assistant positions are not filled). Overloads pay less now than in the past. Morale is low and continually getting lower. Though upper management are some of the highest paid public workers in the state. The inequality gap is increasing to an unsustainable level.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ruston, LA
pros: decent education for the money they charge undergraduate students
cons: The stipend for PhD students is miserable. And this is probably the only school in the country where PhD students have to pay full tution even after finishing their required courses. I literally lived like a rat , scavenging for food, getting into debts and barely making it through school.  No health benefits too.  Monetarily, this is perhaps the worst school for a PhD graduate student to be in and I will not recommend this school to any one unless they remove tution and give a decent stipend.

pros: Relaxed atmosphere allows space to work independently and the convenience of coming to associates for collaborative efforts when questions arise. A smaller community breads close ties, which can be extremely beneficial and productive.
cons: The tight-knit circles can be preventative, turning the advantage of a small community into unintended isolation for those not in the circle. Bureaucracy impedes work-flow and not knowing how to navigate the administration can make it difficult to maintain pace.

review_title: You get what you put in, nothing more
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ruston, LA
pros: Very quiet environment, perfect for someone who is internally driven to study. Ruston is a sleepy town with very little distractions
cons: As a grad student, you are the only one responsible for yourself. You get little to no compensation, very little networking is to be found, and there are few few chances of advancing your career. Tech pretends to be a graduate school, with little to no support for the grad students.

pros: Affordable cost living, laid back lifestyle
cons: At the cost of quality, poor funding, worse assistantship opportunities, bad research, ineffective management and bad focus on priorities e.g. when attention should,be paid at employee salaries (professer salary, gradauate assistships) they focus elsewhere such as building a new annex to lambright fitness centre which no one ueses as a,result all higher faculty attiration rate and low comparitive graduate enrolment.

pros: Good school with affordable tuition. Quarter system and multiple class schedule to choose from. A Tier 1 school with great education. Located between two major cities.
cons: The place it self is kind of boring. There is not much nightlife except for a nightclub. The school has a recreactional center but it is almost crowed in peak hours. Not enough parking.

job_title: TAC Student Assistant in Ruston, LA
pros:
Opportunities to meet coaches and staff as well as be apart of tech athletics. 
Everyone is very close and knows each other by name.
Great understanding of student comes first attitude and are willing to be there for you when you need them if you are there for them when they need you.
cons:
Not really any cons besides when there is nothing to do and you're just waiting around for something to happen.
Can get boring when sports are out of season, and busy when basketball season is going.

review_title: Potentially a fantastic place to work, but they take advantage of student employees.
job_title: Student Content Creator and Photographer in Ruston, LA
pros: The experience was great. They are an esteemed institution with the potential to compete against tier one universities in the country.
cons: In the department, there's no mentoring and no potential for growth. Student workers are taken advantage of, and they have little to no strategies regarding social media.

review_title: Student Worker working to supplement tuition.
pros: The student worker jobs at Tech have flexible schedules, are non-stressful, are catered to student's needs. The pay is good when compared to other no-experience/no-education-required positions.
cons: Some will say that they dislike having to work during the quarter breaks, but for many this is merely an opportunity to work longer hours and make more money.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ruston, LA
pros: I spent 4 years in graduate school here.  I think it is a good engineering school and I liked the smaller city environment of Ruston.  There are a lot of good research programs to get into here and being a smaller university a lot of the work is directly with the supervising professor.
cons: Being a smaller university there is some what of a limit on things to do around the area.

review_title: Great place to work, great environment and lots of growing opportunities.
pros:
Overall, great quality of people you'll have to deal with.
The university is expanding, and there are many opportunities to move up as well.
Ruston is a great place to raise a family.
cons: Ruston is located in the middle of the Bible belt, therefore is not a party school.

review_title: In being a student and a graduate assistant, I have loved my time at Tech.
pros: Tech is a great public university located in quaint Ruston, Louisiana. My experience as a worker has been wonderful. I have learned many organizational skills that will help me in my future ventures.
cons: The pay for an assistantship is pretty limited but they are unable to pay more due to the vast amount of assistants employed.

pros: Explore and develop new approaches in higher education and outreach.  Tremendous organizational and community support.  Good, safe small town atmosphere.
cons: Government funding for higher education declining, but administration diligent in pursuing alternate funding sources and supports employee efforts.

review_title: Great in most ways except salary

review_title: State budget issues are killing higher education
pros: Both the faculty and staff you work with are generally nice and pleasant.  The atmosphere is relaxed.  You don't have to fear trying something and making a mistake.
cons: There are limited advancement opportunities.  Due to state budget issues salaries have been stagnant for about five years.  There are no benefits beyond medical, dental, vision, etc.  There's little money for training or professional development.
